i have used these notifications in karmic and i really liked them. But the lack of actions really troubled me and i had to go back.

1) I use kepas for local LAN file sharing. When someone tries to send me a file it shows up as a notification with two actions to either accept or reject. This simply does not work with Ayatana.

2) Power manager (PowerDevil) sends a notification that it is about to sleep in 10 seconds. Click cancel to stop. Again...

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
I didn't know about Kepas, will give it a try. Is there no other way than a notification to accept or reject the transfer?

About PowerDevil, I proposed a patch to turn this dialog into a dialog which would not steal focus: it generated quite a large thread on the kde-core-devel mailing list, but it was rejected in the end.
The work-around I am using is to set the timeout to something much longer, like 5 minutes, so that you get enough time to plug your laptop, cancelling the scheduled suspend.

replies.author: Kishore
replies.message: Nope. There is no other way to accept/reject.

author: Ted Gould
message:
@Kishore: Obvoiusly applications have to be aware whether the notifications they're sending are passive or contain actions. If they just assume there will be buttons, then the messages and the interactions will be sub-optimal. Unfortunately, these situations have to be worked through on an app-by-app basis. There are some general guidelines on the Notify OSD webpages.
@Fri13: Link? I have seen opinions on this, and other things. The reality is that if passive notifications didn't work at all, the clock on your wall would be useless :) There is a time and place for both, I doubt anyone could say "one way works" universally.

replies.author: Ted Gould
replies.message:
Thanks for the link. Just to be clear, it's not a usability study, but a literature review. And I disagree with Celeste on her conclusions (she knows this). I think that the key difference there is the discussion on whether a notification system that allows actions can ever be a "glance" type interruption. I would argue that anytime a user has to evaluate whether they need to interact with the notification it has already moved up the interruption scale from "glance."

Unfortunately, I don't believe that user tests can validate this or not because a user would have to use the various notification systems being tested for an extended period of time before they would know what to do with them. Locking people in a room for days is probably impractical :)

Today, I think this is going to have to be decided by user perference. Choose yours!
